stages.title: Contract & Setup
stages.summary: Meticulously review the contract against the original bid, execute, and submit all required startup documents.

content.overview: Starting a project on a positive note is crucial for success. This phase involves a thorough examination of the Contract or Purchase Order to ensure alignment with your original bid.

steps.title: Review Contract/Purchase Order
details: Verify Contract Amount matches original bid.
Compare Scope of Work listed to original bid.
Verify Project Details (name, location, job number).
Collect Key Contact Info (PM, Superintendent, Billing).
Confirm Installation Responsibilities (material, labor, equipment, ADA compliance).
Check Timeline & Coordination Requirements.

steps.title: Compare to Original Bid
details: Request all bid documents (drawings, specs, quotes) from estimator.
Identify discrepancies (typos, incorrect entries) before signing.
PRO TIP: Consult with GC's Project Manager about signage scope before executing contract.

steps.title: Execute Contract
details: Sign contract (including all initial pages).
Email signed document to GC's PM or contracts administrator.
Ensure you receive a fully executed contract (signed by both parties) in return.

steps.title: Submit Start-up Documents
details: Certificate of Insurance (COI): Required for every contract. Must include General Liability, Auto, Workers' Comp.
Schedule of Values (SOV): Detailed breakdown of bid for billing purposes.
W-9 Form: For tax identification.
Safety Plan: Simple one-page outline adhering to OSHA standards.

proTips: If there's a significant time gap since the bid, check for material/labor cost increases.
Address disputes early to maintain negotiating leverage.
Always get written confirmation of any resolutions or contract amendments.
A handshake may seal intent, but signatures seal destiny.

stages.title: Design & Approval
stages.summary: Submit manufacturer drawings and material samples to the GC for formal architect review and approval.

content.overview: This phase bridges the gap between the contract scope and the physical product. It ensures that what is built matches the architect's vision and the client's needs.

steps.title: Prepare Submittals
details: Gather manufacturer drawings and material samples.
Create a Submittal Transmittal sheet listing all items.
Ensure all samples are clearly labeled with project name and spec number.

steps.title: Submit to GC
details: Send digital copies of drawings via email or project portal.
Ship physical samples to the GC's office (or Architect's office if directed).
Track submission date to monitor approval timeline.

steps.title: Review & Revise
details: Receive 'Redlines' (markups) from Architect.
Revise drawings based on comments (e.g., 'Change font size', 'Verify color match').
Resubmit for final approval if 'Revise and Resubmit' is noted.

proTips: Never start production without 'Approved' or 'Approved as Noted' submittals.
Keep a log of all submittal dates and responses.
If the Architect changes the scope during review (e.g., 'Add 2 more signs'), issue a Change Order request immediately.

stages.title: Production
stages.summary: Once submittals are approved, formally release orders to manufacturers and confirm production lead times.

content.overview: With approvals in hand, the project moves to fabrication. This stage is about managing vendors, timelines, and quality control before items reach the site.

steps.title: Release for Fabrication
details: Send 'Release for Production' email to manufacturers.
Attach the FINAL approved drawings (do not rely on old versions).
Confirm pricing has not changed since the quote.

steps.title: Track Lead Times
details: Get a confirmed ship date from the manufacturer.
Update the GC's Project Manager on the expected delivery schedule.
Buffer the schedule: Add 3-5 days to the manufacturer's date for safety.

steps.title: Quality Control (Pre-Ship)
details: Request photos of finished goods before they crate/ship.
Verify colors, spelling, and dimensions against approved drawings.
Check for mounting hardware inclusion.

proTips: Don't just email—call to confirm they received the order.
Double-check that the 'Ship To' address is correct (Job site vs. Warehouse).
Ensure the manufacturer labels crates with the Project Name and Sign Type.

stages.title: Installation
stages.summary: Coordinate logistics with installers and the on-site superintendent to ensure the site is ready for installation.

content.overview: The physical execution of the work. Success here depends on coordination, site readiness, and having the right equipment.

steps.title: Pre-Install Coordination
details: Contact Site Superintendent 1 week prior to confirm site readiness.
Verify wall blocking is installed (for heavy signs).
Confirm electrical rough-ins are complete and in the right spot.

steps.title: Logistics & Equipment
details: Schedule boom trucks, lifts, or cranes if needed.
Ensure installers have badging/safety gear (PPE) required for the site.
Coordinate delivery of signs to coincide with installer arrival.

steps.title: Execution & Sign-Off
details: Install signs per approved drawings.
Take photos of completed work (Close-up and Wide shots).
Get 'Work Order' signed by Site Superintendent verifying completion.

proTips: Always have a 'Plan B' for bad weather on exterior installs.
Bring touch-up paint and extra fasteners.
If a sign can't be installed due to site conditions, document it with photos immediately.

stages.title: Closeout
stages.summary: Submit final pay applications for retainage and provide all required warranty and maintenance documents.

content.overview: The final lap. Getting paid and providing the owner with the documents they need to maintain their new signage.

steps.title: Punch List
details: Walk the site with the GC to identify any deficiencies.
Fix any issues (scratches, loose letters) immediately.
Get final sign-off on the Punch List.

steps.title: Closeout Documents
details: Submit Warranty Letter (typically 1 year parts/labor).
Provide Maintenance Instructions (cleaning, bulb replacement).
Submit As-Built Drawings (if changes were made during install).

steps.title: Final Billing
details: Submit final AIA G702/G703 Pay App.
Bill for 100% of contract including Retainage.
Provide Final Lien Waiver.

proTips: Don't wait for the GC to ask for closeouts—send them as soon as install is done.
Retainage is often held until the entire building is done—stay on top of it.
A smooth closeout leaves a lasting impression for the next project.
